Description: Body sherd with top of cul (mended from three fragments) of Chian Grand Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black with two added white bands; exterior: painted decoration consisting of parts of two confronted hoplites in outline (on left, bare legs and feet of one; on right, shield with black centre and dot and billet border, and legs with greaves of other); below, maeander frieze running left between lines.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1926,1117.2. Lemos describes this sherd as belonging to the Naukratis Painter and/or the Naukratis Painter’s Group. The painter and the group are named after a chalice found at Naukratis and the slip on all vessels from this group is a light beige to almost creamy white. Rim patterns are very simple and there is no filling ornament. However, the depiction of figures is very elaborate. Clothing is rendered highly decorated and naked skin is expertly portrayed. However, unlike other sherds by the Naukratis Painter, the exterior decoration here is mostly in outline and the interior decoration is sparse. The thickness and size of the sherd suggest that the vase was a heavy chalice.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 111, p. 279, no. 762, pl. 99) (incorrectly labelled 1888,0601.460.d and incorrectly labelled no. 761 on pl. 99)
Price 1924 / Pottery of Naukratis (pl. IX, no. 7)
